front.title: Discovery of path characteristics using STUN

abstract.t: A host with multiple interfaces needs to choose the best interface for communication. Oftentimes, this decision is based on a static configuration and does not consider the path characteristics, which may affect the user experience.

This document describes a mechanism for an endpoint to find the path characteristics using Session Traversal Utilities for NAT (STUN). This information can be used to influence endpoint's Interactive Connectivity Establishment (ICE) candidate pair selection algorithm.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: ICE uses a prioritization formula to perform connectivity checks, in which the most preferred address pairs are tested first and when a sufficiently good pair is discovered, that pair is used for communications and ICE connectivity tests are stopped. This approach works well for an endpoint with a single interface, but is too simplistic for endpoints with multiple interfaces. ICE connectivity checks can be used measure the path characteristics but the problem is that STUN responses from re-transmitted requests are indistinguishable.

This draft extends STUN to distinguish STUN responses from re-transmitted requests and helps client determine path characteristics like round-trip time (RTT) and packet loss in each direction, which can be used by the controlling agent to influence the ICE candidate pair priority and relayed candidates priority .

section.title: Path characteristics determination mechanism
section.t: When multiple paths are available for communication, the first approach is to send an ICE connectivity check across each path and choose the path with the best round trip time. Choosing the path with the best round trip time is a reasonable approach, but re-transmits can cause an otherwise-good path to appear flawed. However, STUN's retransmission algorithm cannot determine the round-trip time if a STUN packet is re-transmitted, because each packet retransmission is identical. To resolve that, this document changes that retransmission behavior for idempotent packets. In addition to determining RTT, it is also desirable to detect which path direction caused packet loss, described as "bi-directional path characteristics," below. This is achieved by defining a new STUN attribute and requiring compliant STUN (TURN, ICE) servers to count retransmitted request packets.

This specification defines a new comprehension-optional STUN attribute PATH-CHARACTERISTIC. PATH-CHARACTERISTIC will have a STUN Type TBD-CA. This type is in the comprehension-optional range, which means that STUN agents can safely ignore the attribute if they do not understand it.

If a client wishes to determine the path characteristics then it inserts PATH-CHARACTERISTIC attribute in STUN request. In PATH-CHARACTERISTIC attribute client sends the number of times the STUN request is retransmitted with the same Transaction ID. The server would echo back the retransmission count in the response so that client can distinguish STUN responses from re-transmitted requests. Client can thus use STUN requests and responses to calculate the round-trip time (RTT). The server MAY also convey number of times it received the request with the same Transaction ID and number of responses it has sent for the STUN request to the client. This information can be used by the client to determine packet loss in each direction.

section.title: The PATH-CHARACTERISTIC attribute in request
section.t: The PATH-CHARACTERISTIC attribute in the request takes a 1-byte Value, which means that the Length is 1 and 3 bytes of padding are required after the value. When sending a STUN request, the PATH-CHARACTERISTIC attribute allows a client to indicate to the server that it wants to determine path characteristics. If the client receives a STUN response with error code 420 (Unknown Attribute) and PATH-CHARACTERISTIC is listed in the UNKNOWN-ATTRIBUTE attribute of the message, the client SHOULD retransmit the original request without the PATH-CHARACTERISTIC attribute. However this case is not expected due to the use of a comprehension-optional attribute type.

This specification changes one the STUN message structuring rules explained in section 6 of that resends of the same request as usual reuse the same transaction ID, ReTransCnt in PATH-CHARACTERISTIC attribute will be incremented by 1 for every re-transmission and the re-transmitted STUN request MUST be bit-wise identical to the previous request except for the ReTransCnt value.
The format of the value in PATH-CHARACTERISTIC attribute in the request is:

list.t: Number of times request is re-transmitted with the same transaction ID to the server.

section.title: The PATH-CHARACTERISTIC attribute in response
section.t: When a server receives a STUN request that includes a PATH-CHARACTERISTIC attribute, it processes the request as per the STUN specification plus the specific rules mentioned here. The server checks the following:

list.t: If the PATH-CHARACTERISTIC attribute is not recognized, ignore the attribute because its type indicates that it is comprehension- optional. This should be the existing behavior as explained in section 3.1 of .
The server that supports PATH-CHARACTERISTIC attribute MUST echo back ReTransCnt in the response.

If the server is stateless or does not want to remember the transaction ID then it would populate value 0 for the ReqTransCnt and RespTransCnt fields in PATH-CHARACTERISTIC attribute sent in the response .If the server is stateful then it populates ReqTransCnt with the number of times it received the STUN request with the same transaction ID and RespTransCnt with the number of responses it has sent for the STUN request.

The fields are described below: Copied from request.
Number of times request is received from the client with the same transaction ID.
Number of responses sent to the client for the same transaction ID.

section.title: Multiple Interfaces and other usecases
section.t: The STUN attribute defined in this specification can be used by applications in the following scenarios:

list.t: When an endpoint has multiple interfaces (for example 3G, 4G, WiFi, VPN, etc.), an ICE agent can choose the interfaces for media streams according to the path characteristics. After STUN responses to STUN checks are received, the ICE agent using regular nomination can sort the ICE candidate pairs according to the path characteristics discovered using STUN. The controlling agent can assign highest priority to candidate pair which best fulfills the desired path characteristics.

When a host has multiple interfaces available an MPRTP application can choose the interface for the primary subflow and interfaces for subsequent subflows according to the path characteristics discovered using STUN.
The STUN extension proposed in this specification can also be used to choose a TURN server that provides the best user experience (section 3.1 of ).

section.title: Security Considerations
section.t: Security considerations discussed in are to be taken into account. STUN requires the 96 bits transaction ID to be uniformly and randomly chosen from the interval 0 .. 2**96-1, and be cryptographically strong. This is good enough security against an off-path attacker. An on-path attacker can either inject a fake response or modify the values in PATH-CHARACTERISTIC attribute to mislead the client and server, this attack can be mitigated using STUN authentication. As PATH-CHARACTERISTIC is expected to be used between peers using ICE, and ICE uses STUN short-term credential mechanism the risk of on-path attack influencing the messages is minimal. However, an attacker could corrupt, remove, or delay an ICE request or response, in order to discourage that path from being used.
